awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Studies of Magnetohydrodynamics with Hall Effect
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic reconnection is a fundamental process in highly conducting plasmas, which allows for rapid changes in the configuration of the magnetic flux lines, with the conversion of magnetic to kinetic energy. Solar flares, violent events with significant impact to telecommunications and the electric grid, may involve magnetic reconnection in a large scale. Magnetic reconnection is inherently a multi-scale process and causes difficulties in laboratory experimental study, satellite observations, and computational simulations. During magnetic reconnection, the magnetic force can create thin localized region wherein the elevated voltage difference generates intense electric currents and dissipation - the Hall effect. The Hall Magnetohydrodynamics (Hall MHD) model has recently received increasing attention because of its improvements in predicting the fast-changing nature of magnetic reconnection compared to other models. Nevertheless, the mathematical theory of this model is far from being complete. This project will address fundamental mathematical questions for the Hall MHD model and provide theoretical insights for experiments and numerical simulations. The project will involve a graduate student in the research. 

The Hall MHD model is mathematically challenging due to the usual convective nonlinearities and the additional source term given by the Hall effect. The main objectives are: 1) Explore the largest possible space of well-posedness corresponding to the major scalings in the system. 2) Search the optimal Sobolev spaces in which the model is well-posed. 3) Examine ill-posedness of solutions in some physically relevant spaces. 4) Seek minimal conditions for weak solutions to satisfy energy identity. 5) Study the asymptotic behavior of solutions and stability of the steady state. The project will combine known tools from harmonic analysis and partial differential equations, and develop new methods to study these questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The support of the grant has led to fruitful research outcome reflected in the publications to be listed. It has also given the PI the opportunity to engage in educational activities giving rise to several broader impacts. 

In collaboration with students and other researchers, the PI has accumulated various contributions toward a better understanding of MHD during the support period of this grant. The intellectual merit of the outcome is the advancement on several mathematical topics for MHD, well-posedness issues in different contexts, ill-posedness behavior of weak solutions with low regularity, conditional regularity problem and singularity formation for simplified models of MHD. Below is a list of the publications on these findings.

1. M. Dai. Local well-posedness of the Hall-MHD system in $H^s(\mathbb R^n)$ with $s>\frac n2$. Mathematische nachrichten. DOI: 10.1002/mana.201800107, 2018.

2. M. Dai and H. Liu. Long time behavior of solutions to the 3D Hall-magneto-hydrodynamics system with one diffusion. Journal of Differential Equations, Vol. 266: 7658--7677, 2019.

3. A. Cheskidov and M. Dai. Kolmogorov's dissipation number and the number of degrees of freedom for the 3D Navier-Stokes equations. Proceedings of the Royal Society of Edinburg, Section A, Vol. 149(2): 429--446, 2019.

4. M. Dai and H. Liu. Applications of harmonic analysis techniques to regularity problems of dissipative equations. Contemporary Mathematics, AMS, Vol. 748: 35--56, 2020.

5. A. Cheskidov and M. Dai. Discontinuity of weak solutions to the 3D NSE and MHD equations in critical and supercritical spaces. Journal of Mathematical Analysis and Applications, 481(2), 123494, 2020.

6. A. Cheskidov and M. Dai. On the determining wavenumber for the nonautonomous subcritical SQG equation. Journal of Dynamics and Differential Equations, 32(3): 1511--1525, 2020.

7. M. Dai and H. Liu. Low modes regularity criterion for a chemotaxis-Navier-Stokes system. Communications on Pure and Applied Analysis, Vol. 19(5): 2713--2735, 2020. 

8. M. Dai. Blow-up of a dyadic model with intermittency dependence for the Hall MHD. Physica D: Nonlinear Phenomena, Vol.428, 133066, 2021.

9. M. Dai. Local well-posedness of the Hall-MHD system in optimal Sobolev spaces. Journal of Differential Equations, Vol. 289: 159--181, 2021.

10. M. Dai. Non-uniqueness of Leray-Hopf weak solutions of the 3D Hall-MHD system. SIAM Journal of Analysis, 53(5):5979--6016, 2021.

11. M. Dai, M. Hoeller, Q. Peng and X. Zhang. Kolmogorov's dissipation number and determining wavenumber for dyadic models.  arXiv: 2108.12913, 2021.

12. A. Cheskidov and M. Dai. The number of degrees of freedom for the 2D Navier-Stokes equation: a connection with Kraichnan's theory of turbulence. arXiv:2112.11606, 2021.

13. M. Dai. Blow-up of dyadic MHD models with forward energy cascade. International Mathematics Research Notices, to appear, 2022.

14. M. Dai. Phenomenologies of intermittent Hall MHD turbulence. DCDS-Series B, Vol. 27(10):5535--5560, 2022.

15. M. Dai and S. Friedlander. Dyadic models for ideal MHD. Journal of Mathematical Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 24, 21, 2022. 

16. M. Dai and S. Friedlander. Uniqueness and non-uniqueness results for dyadic MHD models. Journal of Nonlinear Science, to appear, 2022.

17. M. Dai, J. Krol and H. Liu. On uniqueness and helicity conservation of weak solutions to the electron-MHD system.  Journal of Mathematical Fluid Mechanics, Vol. 24, 69, 2022.

18. M. Dai and H. Liu. On well-posedness of the generalized Hall-magneto-hydrodynamics. Zeitschrift fur angewandte Mathematik und Physik. To appear, 2022.

19. M. Dai, B. Vyas, and X. Zhang. 1D model for the 3D magnetohydrodynamics. Journal of Nonlinear Science, to appear, 2022.

20. A. Cheskidov, M. Dai and S. Friedlander. Dyadic models for fluid equations: a survey.  arXiv:2209.10203, 2022.

21. M. Dai. Almost sure existence of global weak solutions for supercritical electron MHD.  arXiv: 2201.08161, 2022.

22. M. Dai.  Almost sure well-posedness for Hall MHD.  arXiv: 2202.04265, 2022.

23. M. Dai. Reduced models for electron magnetohydrodynamics: well-posedness and singularity formation. arXiv:2204. 01951, 2022.

24. M. Dai and C. Wu. Dissipation wavenumber and regularity for electron magnetohydrodynamics. arXiv:2210.14345, 2022.

The broader impacts of the support include educational, societal and scientific broader impacts. Educational benefits include training graduate students, providing research opportunities for undergraduate students, and increasing the participation rate of women and underrepresented ethnic groups in research. The PI has mentored undergraduate students Benjamin Farrell, Donato Jimenez, Jacob Krol, Shekar Mukesh, Chaitali Naik, Le Rayah Neely-Brown, Patricia Wilk, etc., on projects of magnetic waves. She has supervised the undergraduate student Bhkati Vyas to publish the article 19 above. Han Liu successfully defended his PhD thesis under the PI's supervision. The PI also supervised Margaret Hoeller to obtain a Master degree. The PI is supervising two more graduate students Qirui Peng and Chao Wu. She has also made contributions in social empowerment through mathematics by outreach activities to elementary and middle shools of Chicago area. The broader impacts from the scientific perspective is the potential benefit for applied sciences. The outcome is expected to assist space weather forecast and minimize radiation damage caused by violent events related to magnetic reconnection.
